9. ........ Qxd5 - both sides havedeveloped their kingside pieces and castled.  Move 7 appeared to blunder a piece for a pawn but a fork trick on d5 regained the piece.  The centre has been liquidated as a result.  White still has a lead in development and black now goes into reverse but luckily I just about manage to clear my back row by move 14.

15....... Bf6 - improves the position of the prelate - protects g7 and hits at b2 - this will be a crucial square for black later on in the game.  I am now fully developed but I need to centralise my rooks.

19. ......... fxe6 - a couple more pieces are exchanged and the e pawn is an isolani but now look at that dsb on that long diagonal pointing towards b2 in my previous note.  The Wicked Witch of the West is en prise so she moves to e3 forking a and e pawns.  To avoid losing a pawn my bishop takes on b2 to break up white's queenside pawns.

25. Rxa7?? - now white, for taking jstevens1's a pawn without consent I fine you two material points!!!

25. ........ Bc5!! - this bishop forks the rook on a7 and the white pawn on f2 - notice that the king retreat unmasked an attacking battery from the rook on f8.  The best white can now do is give up the exchange by backing off the rook from a7 to a1.  I now collect  the two material points over the next two moves.

30.  ....... Rxc2 - I could have taken this pawn a couple of moves ago but decide to improve the position of my rooks by piling up on the e2 knight.  This knight escapes houdini style but I still manage to keep the pressure on.

35 ........ Rxe1 - after a bit of shilly shallying over the last few moves I am glad to exchange off one pair of rooks - now it really is rook and pawn against a knight.  I should have been confident of winning this one but my opponent was more than 200 points north of my rating and this is only the second time in my entire life that I have beaten an 1800  player.  The last time this happened was 10 years ago when I had a BCF rating of 80 (Elo 1240) and my opponent's was BCF 153 (Elo 1824)!  So this was very nerve wracking, especially as I had to watch where I put my rook and my king to evade dastardly knight forks.

42. ........ Kg6 - after the spite check I play my king to g6, eyeing up the h pawn.  When that falls white will certainly not be able to win should I walk into a knight fork.  But before I could carry out this plan my opponent waved the white flag.  I am soooo relieved!!!
